trustfund: TF020460-NORWEGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF037852-MALAWI - ROAD MAINTENANCE AND REHABILITATION

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Tanzania Second
            Integrated Roads Projects (IRP) were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned include the following:
            Both the IRPII and IRPI, which was closed in 1999, had
            similar developmental objectives, outcomes and issues. It
            would have made much sense to delay the commencement of the
            IRPII and have the reforms planned under IRPI implemented
            first. If this had been followed, the design of IRPII would
            have benefited from the experience of the former project
            which was rated unsatisfactory. The design and
            implementation arrangement of the project should have given
            more attention to improving the limited capacity of the
            implementing agencies and prepared a less ambitious project.
            Attempts to build institutional capacity without appropriate
            reforms are likely to be frustrated and become
            unsustainable. In-country presence of Bank staff is critical
            for success of projects, particular transport infrastructure
            development, that have lengthy preparatory and procurement
            phases. A strong monitoring and evaluation capacity should
            be inbuilt in project preparation and supervision.
